lexicalItems.sourceContext: For centuries, historians and archaeologists have puzzled over the many mysteries of Stonehenge, a prehistoric monument that took an estimated 1,500 years to erect.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: For centuries, historians and archaeologists have puzzled over the many mysteries of Stonehenge, a prehistoric monument that took an estimated 1,500 years to erect.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...to dig a massive circular ditch and bank, or henge.

phase3Production.content: The sailors hoisted the sails to catch the wind.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...engineering haul these boulders, which weigh up to four tons, over such a great distance?

phase3Production.content: The new discovery challenges a long-standing theory about the extinction of the dinosaurs.

phase3Production.content: The children sat on a fallen tree trunk to eat their picnic.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have moved the large rocks from one place (land) to another (flat floating structures).

lexicalItems.sourceContext: More recent archaeological hypotheses have them transporting the bluestones with supersized wicker baskets on a combination of ball bearings and long grooved planks, hauled by oxen.

phase3Production.content: She carried the fresh vegetables from her garden in a large wicker basket.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...on a combination of ball bearings and long grooved planks, hauled by oxen.

phase3Production.content: The wheels of the skateboard spun smoothly on their new ball bearings.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...long grooved planks, hauled by oxen.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Pulled with great effort by castrated male cattle used as draft animals.

phase3Production.content: While the film was a box office success, many critics maintain that its plot was weak.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: More recently, signs of illness and injury in the human remains unearthed at Stonehenge...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Dấu hiệu của bệnh tật và thương tích

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Indications or evidence of disease and physical harm.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Dấu hiệu của bệnh tật và thương tích

phase3Production.content: The ancient skeleton showed clear signs of illness and injury, including several healed fractures.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...descended from the original builders.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Những người xây dựng ban đầu

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The first people who constructed a particular building or monument.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Những người xây dựng ban đầu

phase3Production.content: Little is known about the original builders of the ancient city.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: at different times of the year
lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...eclipses at different times of the year.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Vào các thời điểm khác nhau trong năm

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: During various periods within a year.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Vào các thời điểm khác nhau trong năm

phase3Production.content: The festival is held at different times of the year depending on the local traditions.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...led a group of British archaeologists to speculate that it was considered a place of healing...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Các nhà khảo cổ học người Anh

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Scientists from Britain who study human history and prehistory through the excavation of sites and the analysis of artefacts and other physical remains.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các nhà khảo cổ học người Anh

phase3Production.content: A team of British archaeologists made a significant discovery in the Egyptian desert.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Some believe that they were probably immigrants from the European continent...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The continent of Europe, sometimes excluding the British Isles.

phase3Production.content: After touring the UK, they took a ferry to the European continent to continue their travels.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: For centuries, historians and archaeologists have puzzled over the many mysteries of Stonehenge...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Các nhà sử học và khảo cổ học

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Experts who study the past, with historians focusing on written records and archaeologists focusing on physical remains.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các nhà sử học và khảo cổ học

phase3Production.content: A team of historians and archaeologists is working together to uncover the secrets of the ancient city.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...it is comprised of roughly 100 massive upright stones placed in a circular layout.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: An arrangement of things in the shape of a circle.

phase3Production.content: The garden was designed with a beautiful circular layout of flower beds.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Archaeologists believe England’s most iconic prehistoric ruin was built in several stages...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A number of distinct periods in the development of something.

phase3Production.content: The construction of the new bridge will be completed in several stages over the next two years.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Deep pits dating back to that era and located within the circle may have once held a ring of timber posts...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Có niên đại từ thời đại đó

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Originating from that specific period in history.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Có niên đại từ thời đại đó

phase3Production.content: The museum has a collection of pottery dating back to the Roman era.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...may have once held a ring of timber posts, according to some scholars.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A circular arrangement of wooden poles set upright in the ground.

phase3Production.content: Archaeological evidence suggests the site was originally a large ring of timber posts.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...may have once held a ring of timber posts, according to some scholars.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: As stated or believed by certain academics or experts.
relatedCollocates: in the view of some experts

phase3Production.content: The manuscript is, according to some scholars, the oldest surviving text in that language.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...haul these boulders, which weigh up to four tons, over such a great distance?

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have a maximum weight of a particular amount.

phase3Production.content: Some adult blue whales can weigh up to 200 tons.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...Stonehenge’s builders fashioned sledges and rollers out of tree trunks...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Simple machines used for transporting heavy loads; a sledge is a vehicle on runners for conveying loads, and rollers are cylindrical objects placed underneath a load to allow it to be moved.

phase3Production.content: Ancient Egyptians likely used a system of sledges and rollers to move the massive stone blocks for the pyramids.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...to lug the bluestones from the Preseli Hills.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To carry or drag a heavy or bulky object with great effort.

phase3Production.content: He had to lug his heavy suitcase up three flights of stairs.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...alternatively, they may have towed each stone with a fleet of vessels.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have pulled a boat or vehicle along through water by means of a rope, chain, or tow bar.

phase3Production.content: The broken-down car was towed to the nearest garage.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: As early as the 1970s, geologists have been adding their voices to the debate over how Stonehenge came into being.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Experts in geology, the science that deals with the earth's physical structure and substance, its history, and the processes which act on it.

phase3Production.content: Geologists studied the rock formations to understand the history of the landscape.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: adding their voices to the debate
lexicalItems.sourceContext: As early as the 1970s, geologists have been adding their voices to the debate over how Stonehenge came into being.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Góp tiếng nói vào cuộc tranh luận

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To join in a discussion or argument by expressing one's opinion.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Góp tiếng nói vào cuộc tranh luận

phase3Production.content: Many parents are adding their voices to the debate about school safety.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...hauling giant stones from faraway Wales...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Distant in space or time.

phase3Production.content: She dreamed of traveling to faraway lands and experiencing different cultures.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...wondering how the forces of nature could possibly have delivered the exact number of stones needed to complete the circle.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The precise and correct quantity.

phase3Production.content: It is difficult to determine the exact number of people who attended the festival.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Some 50 of these stones are now visible on the site, which may once have contained many more.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Có thể nhìn thấy tại địa điểm

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Able to be seen at the particular location.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Có thể nhìn thấy tại địa điểm
relatedCollocates: can be seen at the location

phase3Production.content: The foundations of the ancient Roman villa are still visible on the site today.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: In the 17th century, archaeologist John Aubrey made the claim that Stonehenge was the work of druids...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To state or assert that something is the case, typically without providing evidence or proof.

phase3Production.content: The company made the claim that its new product could cure baldness, but it was later proven false.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...who had important religious, political and judicial roles in Celtic society.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Functions relating to the law, courts of law, or the administration of justice.

phase3Production.content: In many ancient societies, priests often held important judicial roles.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Even today, people who identify as modern druids continue to gather at Stonehenge for the summer solstice.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To consider oneself to be a member of a particular group.

phase3Production.content: She is an artist who does not identify as belonging to any particular movement.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...radiocarbon dating demonstrated that Stonehenge stood more than 1,000 years before the Celts inhabited the region.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have existed or been in place for longer than a particular period.

phase3Production.content: The ancient castle has stood for more than 800 years on that hilltop.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Many modern historians and archaeologists now agree that several distinct tribes of people contributed to Stonehenge...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have given something, especially money or effort, in order to help achieve or provide something.

phase3Production.content: Many different cultures have contributed to the development of modern mathematics.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...each undertaking a different phase of its construction.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Đảm nhận một giai đoạn khác

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To take responsibility for and begin a distinct stage of a process.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Đảm nhận một giai đoạn khác

phase3Production.content: A new team will be undertaking the final phase of the project.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Bones, tools and other artefacts found on the site seem to support this hypothesis.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To provide evidence that helps to prove that this proposed explanation is true.

phase3Production.content: The new fossil discoveries seem to support the hypothesis that birds evolved from dinosaurs.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Later, it is believed, groups with advanced tools and a more communal way of life left their mark on the site.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Tools that are modern and highly developed.

phase3Production.content: The Bronze Age began when humans started making advanced tools out of metal.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...while others maintain that they were probably native Britons...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To assert or insist that something is true.

phase3Production.content: Despite the evidence against him, the suspect continued to maintain that he was innocent.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: If the facts surrounding the architects and construction of Stonehenge remain shadowy at best...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The pieces of information that are related to or connected with a particular situation or event.

phase3Production.content: The police are still investigating the facts surrounding the mysterious disappearance.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the purpose of the striking monument is even more of a mystery.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: An even greater puzzle or something that is even more difficult to understand or explain.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Còn là một bí ẩn lớn hơn

phase3Production.content: How the ancient Egyptians built the pyramids is a great puzzle, but why they built them is even more of a mystery.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the cluster of megalithic stones operated as a form of astronomical calendar...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have functioned or worked as a type of something.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Hoạt động như một dạng của

phase3Production.content: The ancient abacus operated as a form of early calculator.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...lacked the knowledge necessary to predict such events...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Dự đoán những sự kiện như vậy

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To say or estimate that a specified thing of that kind will happen in the future.
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Dự đoán những sự kiện như vậy

phase3Production.content: Modern meteorologists use complex computer models to predict such events as hurricanes and tornadoes.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...led a group of British archaeologists to speculate that...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have caused a number of people to think or believe something.

phase3Production.content: The surprising discovery led a group of scientists to reconsider their initial hypothesis.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...perhaps because bluestones were thought to have curative powers.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Were believed to possess a particular quality or ability.

phase3Production.content: In ancient times, certain springs were thought to have magical healing properties.
